ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Lectures twice a week which were posted online
All of the lectures were virtual but we had the option to go to Davies Auditorium to watch the lectures online as well. There was also an in-person presentation.
Professor also provided an optional in-person component to watch the lectures live from Davies Auditorium.
Homework assignments, OH
Demos and lots of office hours
Live virtual lecture, one in person presentation, live zoom lectures projected in auditorium for optional in-person lecture component
Recorded lectures as well as live virtual lectures.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Learned how to do CAD. Most importantly, we were taught how to do simulations on our models so we can determine failure modes during the design process.

Learned that I do not want to design things for a job. Process is very boring when you are told to build thing. Designing things in free time was great.

How to use the functions of SolidWorks more in-depth. Everything including modeling parts, assemblies, static analysis, motion simulation, fluid simulation, design for CAM, and others. Also did some computer graphics assignments in MATLAB to get an insight into how the SolidWorks program actually works mathematically. Very thorough.
Basics of solidworks design and simulations, and to a small extent, matlab coding
This course gives a fantastic overview of the capabilities of Solidworks. It teaches a lot of very useful skills in Solidworks and allows a few of the skills it teaches to be explored deeper.

I already knew SolidWorks, but I still learned a lot by taking this course! I learned how to make use of essentially all of the SolidWorks simulation features, like static analysis, buckling analysis, flow simulations, motion studies, etc.
How to use solidworks, which was extremely foreign before this class. Specifically, how to use it for engineering purposes.
I learned CAD skills!!
CAD skills, design skills, analysis with CAD, FEM and some MATLAB assignments
Very well rounded knowledge of SolidWorks, computer aided design, and how to learn more CAD on my own.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Accessing the software is hard and some of the calculations are very time consuming. Some of the problem sets would take upwards of fifteen hours. Making more consistent rigor on problem sets or giving small breaks between challenging assignments would be appreciated.

Strength is lectures. They are very thorough. Everyone can make something totally unique with the same basis.

I personally really liked being able to skip live lectures and watch them at 2x speed, as it allowed me to skip through parts I already knew and really focus on what I was learning. Also the office hours were well done in the sense that there were plenty of hours to ask for help and the ULAs often stayed past when they were supposed to in order to ensure all students got help. Also, Professor Long did a good job of assisting students personally through email.
CAD is super fun and Professor Long is awesome.

Strengths: interesting homework assignments with design constraint challenges, helpful lectures, useful office hours and good engagement with Prof. Long Weaknesses: remote desktop is extremely glitchy and not a good software, crashes of this program made assignments take many hours longer than they would otherwise, pace in lecture too fast especially with slow virtual desktop which got frustrating, sometimes on assignments we wouldn't learn about assumptions we could make or constraints that should be considered until few days until deadline

Honestly, one of the best courses I've taken as a mechanical engineer. Prof. Long went very in-depth with his lessons and provided extremely useful examples during lecture. Sad to see him go. Yale lost a great one.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Recordings were super useful. We only had recorded lectures so they succeeded. Working with a TA over Zoom is very challenging though for a design class. Therefore, more office hours are probably useful.
I liked how this class was done.
Office hours were helpful
The demos were great.
in person optional component was very helpful, virtual desktop is extremely bad and hindered my learning

Prof. Long did very well in adapting his class to the pandemic. All lectures were recorded and posted (super, super useful) and the lab portions of the class were replaced with examples during lecture. We were able to meet a couple of times in person for presentations (Prof. Long allowed for students to opt for presenting from home or wherever they were staying), and COVID guidelines were followed pretty strictly which was encouraging to see.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
I would not recommend this class.

This class isn't mentally taxing. Working on the assignments does not require full focus. However, the class is extremely time consuming. The problem sets start off easy and then ramp up in difficulty very quickly and stay very challenging the rest of the course. Some assignments would take three hours. Others would take fifteen hours. Expect some long nights.

The TAs are super useful and SolidWorks is a very fun program to learn. The design process can be satisfying and I definitely designed stuff out of class for fun. Marshall Long is a boring but very good and extremely nice professor.

The reason I do not recommend this class is it is useful if you are dead set on going into industry. Don't take it unless you are certain you want to design things. I found I didn't so this class wasn't for me. Yale prides itself in its liberal arts curriculum and this is probably one of the most pre-professional courses taught at the school.

Honestly you could just teach yourself CAD in like a week. It truly is not that hard. Most engineers do exactly that. If you want a hard but interesting elective and would rather spare your brain by taking a time-sink class, do this. If not, don't. Seriously CAD is extremely easy to teach yourself.

If you're in an engineering discipline, this course is a must-take. SolidWorks and CAD in general is an industry necessity and will greatly help you in any other project you may work on. Even if you don't use CAD or plan to use it, learning CAD gives you a better physical understanding of how machines and assemblies of parts come together and function.

This course is amazing, probably my favorite course at Yale so far. It teaches so many useful skills in Solidworks and I felt like I learned a ton each lecture. It gives a great overview of Solidworks and also allows you to dive a little deeper into some aspects of the software too.

I would recommend! It is a great elective for any engineering student in my opinion, and overall I felt the homeworks were reasonable and the workload was not bad at all until the final project, which I spent MANY hours on.
Yes, if interested in learning to use solidworks.
Absolutely, I knew no CAD before and feel very comfortable now.
Yes, very useful and interesting, feels very real-world applicable, consider taking when Yale desktop facilities can be used because remote desktop is not good
Highly recommend. Will be with another professor because Prof. Long is retiring, but I enjoy using SolidWorks and learning about the small tips and tricks for it may be super useful.
